values.description:
* Upgrade all npm dependencies except for `gulp-useref`, because its API has [changed](https://github.com/jonkemp/gulp-useref/pull/154/files). The fix for that will come in a future PR.

* Upgrade bower dependencies

* Install more fine grained bower components instead of installing all the PolymerElements collections

* Don't include elements which are not being used

* Remove old test
values.title: Upgrade dependencies

summary.raw:
* Upgrade all npm dependencies except for `gulp-useref`, because its API has [changed](https://github.com/jonkemp/gulp-useref/pull/154/files). The fix for that will come in a future PR.

* Upgrade bower dependencies

* Install more fine grained bower components instead of installing all the PolymerElements collections

* Don't include elements which are not being used

* Remove old test
summary.html:
• Upgrade all npm dependencies except for gulp-useref, because its API has changed. The fix for that will come in a future PR.

  • Upgrade bower dependencies

  • Install more fine grained bower components instead of installing all the PolymerElements collections

  • Don't include elements which are not being used

  • Remove old test

values.description:
Similar to [this](#!/osrf/cloudsim-auth/pull-requests/6/https/diff) pull request for `cloudsim-auth` and [this](#!/osrf/cloudsim-portal/pull-requests/18/https/diff) one for `cloudsim-portal`.

* Serve on http by default. Beanstalk's load balancer will be the one serving https.
* Add two `ebextension` files which together configure the beanstalk https. Explanation about them will be added to the [wiki](#!/osrf/cloudsim/wiki/HTTPS) soon.

Currently Codeship deployed the http branch and you can see that it is live in https://dev.cloudsim.io/ . Before this PR is merged, I'll change the deployment pipeline to use the default branch instead.
values.title: HTTPS

summary.raw:
Similar to [this](#!/osrf/cloudsim-auth/pull-requests/6/https/diff) pull request for `cloudsim-auth` and [this](#!/osrf/cloudsim-portal/pull-requests/18/https/diff) one for `cloudsim-portal`.

* Serve on http by default. Beanstalk's load balancer will be the one serving https.
* Add two `ebextension` files which together configure the beanstalk https. Explanation about them will be added to the [wiki](#!/osrf/cloudsim/wiki/HTTPS) soon.

Currently Codeship deployed the http branch and you can see that it is live in https://dev.cloudsim.io/ . Before this PR is merged, I'll change the deployment pipeline to use the default branch instead.
summary.html:
Similar to this pull request for cloudsim-auth and this one for cloudsim-portal.

  • Serve on http by default. Beanstalk's load balancer will be the one serving https.
  • Add two ebextension files which together configure the beanstalk https. Explanation about them will be added to the wiki soon.

Currently Codeship deployed the http branch and you can see that it is live in https://dev.cloudsim.io/ . Before this PR is merged, I'll change the deployment pipeline to use the default branch instead.

values.description:
* Any new user of cloudsim can request to participate in SRC:

    ![req1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/3722556608-req1.png)

    * This creates a `srcsignup-xxx` resource in the widgets server

* Cloudsim admin and src-admins can see a list of pending requests:

    ![req2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/1315229124-req2.png)

* If the admin declines, the `srcsignup-xxx` resource is deleted from the widgets server

* If the admin accepts:

    1. Send a request to the auth server to add the user to team `src-competitors`

    1. If 1. is successful, delete the `srcsignup-xxx` resource from the widgets server

    1. The next time the user logs in, they can see the competitor's kiosk



This pull request removes the need for env variables with user names. Now the cloudsim admin can create teams and add users through the interface.
values.title: Registrations for SRC

summary.raw:
* Any new user of cloudsim can request to participate in SRC:

    ![req1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/3722556608-req1.png)

    * This creates a `srcsignup-xxx` resource in the widgets server

* Cloudsim admin and src-admins can see a list of pending requests:

    ![req2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/1315229124-req2.png)

* If the admin declines, the `srcsignup-xxx` resource is deleted from the widgets server

* If the admin accepts:

    1. Send a request to the auth server to add the user to team `src-competitors`

    1. If 1. is successful, delete the `srcsignup-xxx` resource from the widgets server

    1. The next time the user logs in, they can see the competitor's kiosk



This pull request removes the need for env variables with user names. Now the cloudsim admin can create teams and add users through the interface.
summary.html:
• Any new user of cloudsim can request to participate in SRC:

    • This creates a srcsignup-xxx resource in the widgets server

  • Cloudsim admin and src-admins can see a list of pending requests:

  • If the admin declines, the srcsignup-xxx resource is deleted from the widgets server

  • If the admin accepts:

    1. Send a request to the auth server to add the user to team src-competitors

    2. If 1. is successful, delete the srcsignup-xxx resource from the widgets server

    3. The next time the user logs in, they can see the competitor's kiosk

This pull request removes the need for env variables with user names. Now the cloudsim admin can create teams and add users through the interface.

values.description:
ESLint doesn't work with polymer elements because of the HTML and Javascript mix.

Polymer has a `polymer lint` command which had all sorts of failures, so I just gave up on it for now. 

Also removed some unused gulp commands and unused dependencies.
values.title: Eslint

summary.raw:
ESLint doesn't work with polymer elements because of the HTML and Javascript mix.

Polymer has a `polymer lint` command which had all sorts of failures, so I just gave up on it for now. 

Also removed some unused gulp commands and unused dependencies.
summary.html:
ESLint doesn't work with polymer elements because of the HTML and Javascript mix.

Polymer has a polymer lint command which had all sorts of failures, so I just gave up on it for now.

Also removed some unused gulp commands and unused dependencies.

values.title: Improve coverage, add ESLint for production

values.description:
This is not a final solution for issue #8, but it improves several things:

* Directly typing a client route goes to the correct place:

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/profile

* Navigating to a client route and refreshing the page keeps you in the same place:

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/
    1. Click on the user name to go to `/profile`
    1. Ctrl+R

* Typing an non-existent route redirects you to home

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/lalala

* The only case which needs more work is the case of paths with slashes, like https://dev.cloudsim.io/lalala/lelele. The router is doing something funky, so I shortcut it for now, substituting `/` with `-`. So going to https://dev.cloudsim.io/ariac/leaderboard now redirects to the existing page https://dev.cloudsim.io/ariac-leaderboard
values.title: Improve client routing

summary.raw:
This is not a final solution for issue #8, but it improves several things:

* Directly typing a client route goes to the correct place:

* Typing an non-existent route redirects you to home

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/lalala

* The only case which needs more work is the case of paths with slashes, like https://dev.cloudsim.io/lalala/lelele. The router is doing something funky, so I shortcut it for now, substituting `/` with `-`. So going to https://dev.cloudsim.io/ariac/leaderboard now redirects to the existing page https://dev.cloudsim.io/ariac-leaderboard
summary.html:
This is not a final solution for issue #8, but it improves several things:

  • Directly typing a client route goes to the correct place:

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/profile

  • Navigating to a client route and refreshing the page keeps you in the same place:

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/
    2. Click on the user name to go to /profile
    3. Ctrl+R

  • Typing an non-existent route redirects you to home

    1. https://dev.cloudsim.io/lalala

  • The only case which needs more work is the case of paths with slashes, like https://dev.cloudsim.io/lalala/lelele. The router is doing something funky, so I shortcut it for now, substituting / with -. So going to https://dev.cloudsim.io/ariac/leaderboard now redirects to the existing page https://dev.cloudsim.io/ariac-leaderboard

Competitors:

* Cannot see secure arbiter data

* Should be able to download the keys for their payloads only (this will require changes in `cloudsim-sim` to parse the new options, and `cloudsim-grant` to apply them on init)

Competitors:

* Cannot start competitions

* Cannot see secure arbiter data

* Should be able to download the keys for their payloads only (this will require changes in `cloudsim-sim` to parse the new options, and `cloudsim-grant` to apply them on init)
summary.html:
Competitors:

  • Cannot start competitions

  • Cannot see secure arbiter data

  • Should be able to download the keys for their payloads only (this will require changes in cloudsim-sim to parse the new options, and cloudsim-grant to apply them on init)

values.description:
Competitors should be able to see their payloads status and download SSH keys directly from them.

The status is not updated automatically, so they must refresh the page. Moreover, an admin must be logged in for the updates to work.

This is necessary because the updates are being transferred from the portal to the widgets server through the browser, since the servers shouldn't talk to each other. And since the admin is the only one who has permission to the machines, they must be online.
values.title: Hide admin token from competitor and keep payload status in sync

summary.raw:
Competitors should be able to see their payloads status and download SSH keys directly from them.

The status is not updated automatically, so they must refresh the page. Moreover, an admin must be logged in for the updates to work.

This is necessary because the updates are being transferred from the portal to the widgets server through the browser, since the servers shouldn't talk to each other. And since the admin is the only one who has permission to the machines, they must be online.
summary.html:
Competitors should be able to see their payloads status and download SSH keys directly from them.

The status is not updated automatically, so they must refresh the page. Moreover, an admin must be logged in for the updates to work.

This is necessary because the updates are being transferred from the portal to the widgets server through the browser, since the servers shouldn't talk to each other. And since the admin is the only one who has permission to the machines, they must be online.

values.description:
See issue #27

Move finished rounds to a separate page so they don't clutter the kiosk. Not sure yet what information is useful for users, we can add more info there in the future.

There's also a button to completely erase all records of that round.

![sascfinisheddelete.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/oyRq5d/images/1069298970-sascfinisheddelete.png)
values.title: Separate page for finished SASC rounds

summary.html:
See issue #27

Move finished rounds to a separate page so they don't clutter the kiosk. Not sure yet what information is useful for users, we can add more info there in the future.

There's also a button to completely erase all records of that round.

values.description:
It looks like [this](https://github.com/osrf/gz-token/pull/8) gz-token pull request didn't solve the problem of logging in from a route other than `/`.

I tried a few different auth0 options and didn't manage to make them work:

* Set `callbackUrl` on `lock.show` did not seem to take effect
* Set `redirectUrl` and `responseType: 'token'` on `new Auth0Lock` made the callback work, but we get a query with `code` instead of a token, which doesn't work with our setup.

So for now, the public routes to home all redirect instead of setting an iron page route. This is enough for SASC, but other competitions have public pages which we have to figure out how to handle.
values.title: Redirect to home when logged out

summary.raw:
It looks like [this](https://github.com/osrf/gz-token/pull/8) gz-token pull request didn't solve the problem of logging in from a route other than `/`.

I tried a few different auth0 options and didn't manage to make them work:

* Set `callbackUrl` on `lock.show` did not seem to take effect
* Set `redirectUrl` and `responseType: 'token'` on `new Auth0Lock` made the callback work, but we get a query with `code` instead of a token, which doesn't work with our setup.

So for now, the public routes to home all redirect instead of setting an iron page route. This is enough for SASC, but other competitions have public pages which we have to figure out how to handle.
summary.html:
It looks like this gz-token pull request didn't solve the problem of logging in from a route other than /.

I tried a few different auth0 options and didn't manage to make them work:

  • Set callbackUrl on lock.show did not seem to take effect
  • Set redirectUrl and responseType: 'token' on new Auth0Lock made the callback work, but we get a query with code instead of a token, which doesn't work with our setup.

So for now, the public routes to home all redirect instead of setting an iron page route. This is enough for SASC, but other competitions have public pages which we have to figure out how to handle.
